clinical_study.brief_title: Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) of Brain in ICU Survivors With Cognitive Impairment
clinical_study.official_title: Mechanism of Cognitive Impairment in ICU Survivors :a Study Using Resting-stage fMRI Technique

brief_summary.textblock: Long-term cognitive dysfunction greatly influences patient's quality of life after critical illness. However,its neurophysiological basis remains unknown.This is a one year fMRI study conducted at the Jiangyin people's Hospital. This study utilize resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging(fMRI) to investigate the regional alterations in survivors with cognitive impairment.Further, the investigators hypothesize that these regional changes in fMRI activity are predictive of cognitive impairment.

detailed_description.textblock: Critically ill patients who had hospitalized in ICU at least 2 days and who consented to participate will take the examination of brain fMRI and cognitive assessment before ICU discharge. Individuals of healthy control group are recruited from the community will be made to match them on age,sex and education to individuals recruited for groups of ICU Survivors.Those healthy people will also take the examination of brain fMRI and cognitive assessment.

primary_outcome.description: cognitive impairment assessed with help of MMSE(Mini-mental State Examination).The MMSE has 5 scaled scores; the scores are weighted sums of the questions in each section. The 5 sections and their range of score are listed below:Orientation 0-10;Registration 0-3;Attention and calculation 0-5;Recall 0-3;Language 0-9.Total score range from 0-30. Lower scores = more disability, higher scores = less disability.

arm_group.description: Patients with high risk of cognitive impairment who discharge from ICU

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
ICU Survivors
- Men and women older than 18;Hospitalized in the ICU more than 2 days and Ready to discharge from ICU;
Exclusion Criteria:
- MRI incompatibility; history of neurological disease;poor visual or auditory acuity;Severe brain injury;malignant tumor
